messages.content: How do you say 'to approach (beginning of a process)' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to approach (beginning of a process)' in Yanomami is 'aheai'.

Here are some examples:

- that is approaching
  In Yanomami: thë aheai

- I am approaching
  In Yanomami: ya aheai
How do you say 'to be in the process of approaching' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to be in the process of approaching' in Yanomami is 'aheo'.

Here are some examples:

- it is approaching
  In Yanomami: thë aheo

- I am approaching
  In Yanomami: ya aheo
How do you say 'to have the habit of being found near a certain place at a certain time of day' in Yanomami?
The verb (intransitive) 'to have the habit of being found near a certain place at a certain time of day' in Yanomami is 'aheoprou'.
How do you say '1. to approach (continuation of aheai), 2. to not be afraid of approaching (a relative, a hostile person)' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) '1. to approach (continuation of aheai), 2. to not be afraid of approaching (a relative, a hostile person)' in Yanomami is 'ahetou'.

Here are some examples:

- he whistled when he was near the entrance (of the south of the Orinoco)
  In Yanomami: pei yoka ha a ahetou tëhë a husi koikoimoma

- he is not afraid to approach his mother-in-law
  In Yanomami: pë yesi kë iha a ahetou

- when I was close I sat down
  In Yanomami: ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema
How do you say 'to bring heavy or bulky objects a little closer to where one wants to carry them' in Yanomami?

The verb (transitive) 'to bring heavy or bulky objects a little closer to where one wants to carry them' in Yanomami is 'aheamai'.

Here are some examples:

- this morning I brought the roof poles a little closer
  In Yanomami: hãtõ ya nahiki aheamai kuprei
How do you say 'to be close' in Yanomami?

The adjective 'to be close' in Yanomami can be expressed as: 'ahea', 'ahete'.

Here are some examples:

- probably the herd of tapirs is not very far away
  In Yanomami: warë këki aheare kë thë

- no white person lives near us.
  In Yanomami: thë ki napë no wãri ahepi ma rë mai

- when I was close I sat down
  In Yanomami: ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema

- at the moment the jaguar was close to him, at the moment it was going to jump, he hit it with all his might
  In Yanomami: ira kë a wãri ahetetou totihio tëhë, a mori niyãõ tëhë, ikãri a shëi shoaoma
How do you say 'indicates that an act will be carried out at another place, at a certain distance from the place of utterance' in Yanomami?

The suffix 'indicates that an act will be carried out at another place, at a certain distance from the place of utterance' in Yanomami is 'aharu'.

Here are some examples:

- we will catch up with them (after having traveled a certain distance)
  In Yanomami: yama e ki waroaharayou

- we didn't take long to climb the slope (of the hill that was in front of us).
  In Yanomami: yëtu kë yamaki rë mi ãmõãhãrayopërei
How do you say 'now' in Yanomami?

The adverb 'now' in Yanomami is 'rë'.

Here are some examples:

- now the enemies have approached (lit.: now the game animals have approached) and also it can be The word 'rë' in Yanomami means 'to plan'. It is a Verb (Transitive).
  In Yanomami: rë ahetepraruhe

- I will put you (lit. I plan you) and also it can be The word 'rë' in Yanomami means 'I'. It is a Pronoun.
  In Yanomami: te meteré (lit. te plans ho ko re w ë

- I was under the influence of hallucinogens in the early morning. and also it can be The word 'rë' in Yanomami means 'to'. It is a Particle.
  In Yanomami: rë henaopoi (cha.): en la mañanita estuve bajo la inﬂuencia de alucinógenos.

- he will go behind the dwelling
  In Yanomami: hei ya shikãpi rë rëre hami

- he will go to the forest and also it can be The word 'rë' in Yanomami means 'a/an'. It is a Particle.
  In Yanomami: hei ai yoka rë horere
How do you say '(name)' in Yanomami?

The noun '(name)' in Yanomami can be expressed as: 'ahë', 'ãhi'.

Here are some examples:

- Wake up and make arrowheads (to go to war)
  In Yanomami: wa rii ha rãrini ãhi teshi ta thapa

- bark of the ama ãsi tree.
  In Yanomami: ama ãsi : ãkiki
How do you say 'i approached the luña' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'i approached the luña' in Yanomami is 'etemakema'.

Here are some examples:

- I approached the luña.
  In Yanomami: etemakema: me acerqué al luña
How do you say 'to keep close' in Yanomami?
The verb (transitive) 'to keep close' in Yanomami is 'ahetepou'.
How do you say 'to bring heavy or bulky objects close' in Yanomami?

The verb (transitive) 'to bring heavy or bulky objects close' in Yanomami is 'ahetepramai'.

Here are some examples:

- to bring heavy or bulky objects close to the place where they will be used
  In Yanomami: ahetepramai: aproximar considerablemente ahi objetos pesados o voluminosos al lugar donde se 1 vb. intr. t a h i a i, inc.: 1. Enfriar. yuri pë ahii: quiere hacer uso de ellos
How do you say 'to quickly shorten the distance' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to quickly shorten the distance' in Yanomami is 'ahetetai'.

Here are some examples:

- It didn't take them long to quickly approach (by walking fast) the place (where they were going)
  In Yanomami: yëtu kë thë urihi ahetetaremam a h e: no les llevó mucho tiempo acercarse (caminando rápido) al lugar (adonde iban)

- Again, he didn't delay in quickly approaching the region, restlessness gave him wings.
  In Yanomami: yëtu thë urihi ahetetai rë kõrãyouwei, puhipuhi pëni (mit.): de nuevo, él no tardó en acercarse a la región, la inquietud le daba alas.
How do you say 'to quickly bring something close' in Yanomami?

The verb (transitive) 'to quickly bring something close' in Yanomami is 'ahetetamai'.

Here are some examples:

- He quickly brought the leaves close, lit them on fire, and burned the bees.
  In Yanomami: thë henaki ha ahetetamarini, henaki wakë piyëmakema, pothothe , yopri puu naki hisikikema: aproximó las hojas sin perder un instante, les prendió fuego y quemó las 1. ãhi abejas.
How do you say 'close' in Yanomami?

The adjective 'close' in Yanomami is 'ahetea'.

Here are some examples:

- They live close
  In Yanomami: pë përia ahetea: ellos viven cerca

- There is a herd of tapirs close by here
  In Yanomami: warë kë ki hiraa ahetea: hay una manada de váquiros cerca de acá

- You are still really (too) close
  In Yanomami: wa ahetepraa totihia kë a kure: todavía estás realmente (demasiado) cerca
How do you say 'to get muddy' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to get muddy' in Yanomami is 'ãhiãi'.

Here are some examples:

- The path is starting to get muddy
  In Yanomami: yoka ãhiãi : el camino comienza a estar embarrado
How do you say 'to make muddy' in Yanomami?
The verb (transitive) 'to make muddy' in Yanomami is 'ãhiãmai'.
How do you say 'ant' in Yanomami?

The noun 'ant' in Yanomami can be expressed as: 'kapa', 'kokoku', 'kõnakõna', 'resi', 'titi'.

Here are some examples:

- the night.
  In Yanomami: thë mi titi

- The ant bites me.
  In Yanomami: Kokoku ẽ wãri

- he broke an ant nest with his hands and brought it (near his temporary shelter).
  In Yanomami: kõnakõna pë pesi pata ha kërëtuni, pë pesi praa shoakeyoruma
How do you say 'direct line' in Yanomami?
The noun 'direct line' in Yanomami is 'línea directa'.
How do you say 'elder' in Yanomami?
The adjective 'elder' in Yanomami is 'mayor'.
How do you say 'elder brother, paternal cousin, father or grandfather, father' in Yanomami?

The noun 'elder brother, paternal cousin, father or grandfather, father' in Yanomami is 'ãi'.

Here are some examples:

- my elder brother has let the disease demons escape many times (during shamanic cures), they have already rejected us (him and me)
  In Yanomami: ãimawë no wãri kë ki huhehea waikirayonowë, pëhëki yashuprai waikirayou kë a kuhe (cha.)

- my elder brother killed a dove
  In Yanomami: ãiwëni hoya kë a wai tharei kuroi

- I will sit next to my elder brother
  In Yanomami: ãiwë a wãri iha kamiyë ya roo aheteo

- older brother, here is an excellent palm heart and also it can be The word 'ãi' in Yanomami means '(related word)'. It is an Noun..
  In Yanomami: yei kë ãmo wai wãnipraa kure: hermano mayor, he aquí un excelente palmito
How do you say 'warrior, violent, aggressive, bloodthirsty and merciless people' in Yanomami?

The noun 'warrior, violent, aggressive, bloodthirsty and merciless people' in Yanomami is 'ãiãmo'.

Here are some examples:

- the arrow cane of the ãiãmo people is downriver
  In Yanomami: ãiãmori pë sherekapi si roo yaiokiri (cha.)

- keep calling us cowards: this curare tip will make you see the ãiãmoriwë demon
  In Yanomami: kirii hami wa wã wãri yaimopë, ihi namo wayu ha ãiãmoriwë a ta tarari

- make sure there are many aggressive and fierce wasps.
  In Yanomami: ei kõpina nari pë rë ãiãmorãti, a huu ta mi (wayamou, diálogo ceremonial.)
How do you say 'to be possessed by the ãiãmo demon and become fierce like it' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to be possessed by the ãiãmo demon and become fierce like it' in Yanomami is 'ãiãmoprou'.

Here are some examples:

- the himo wasps became possessed by the ãiãmo demon
  In Yanomami: himo kë ki ãiãmoprou ha kuparuni (cha.)
How do you say 'justicia sp. (acanthaceae), a cultivated plant' in Yanomami?

The noun 'justicia sp. (acanthaceae), a cultivated plant' in Yanomami is 'ãiãmo hena(ki)'.

Here are some examples:

- The ãiãmo hena(ki) plant is dried and its leaves are pulverized, then the powder is inhaled, either alone or mixed, as a hallucinogen.
  In Yanomami: ãiãmo hena(ki) ... La planta se pone a secar y las hojas se pulverizan, luego se inhala el polvo, solo o mezclado, como alucinógeno.
How do you say 'my' in Yanomami?
The pronoun 'my' in Yanomami is 'ia'.
How do you say 'tongue' in Yanomami?

The noun 'tongue' in Yanomami is 'aka'.

Here are some examples:

- what do his threats matter, he wastes his saliva in vain! (lit.: let him scrape his tongue to clean it, his threats do not matter)
  In Yanomami: aka ha hõprarini a wã tetea pëa

- to have the tongue coated with whitish plaques (childhood pathology, probably fungal stomatitis)
  In Yanomami: aka mot h e

- I imagine that he expresses himself badly (lit.: he has a numb tongue)
  In Yanomami: aka moyepi kë thë
How do you say 'i give things away for nothing' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'i give things away for nothing' in Yanomami is 'doy por nada'.

Here are some examples:

- I give things away for nothing, that's what I think.
  In Yanomami: doy por nada, eso es lo que yo pienso
How do you say 'to delirate, to speak incoherently' in Yanomami?
The verb (intransitive) 'to delirate, to speak incoherently' in Yanomami is 'aka porepiai'.
How do you say '(antonym of aka porepiai)' in Yanomami?
The verb (intransitive) '(antonym of aka porepiai)' in Yanomami can be expressed as: 'aka hayu', 'aka piyëkë', 'aka ta'.
How do you say 'to breastfeed (a baby)' in Yanomami?

The verb (transitive) 'to breastfeed (a baby)' in Yanomami is 'aka hesi ke'.

Here are some examples:

- to start breastfeeding
  In Yanomami: aka hesi keo

- to start breastfeeding: the baby starts breastfeeding.
  In Yanomami: aka hesi keo: el niño se pone a tomar la teta
How do you say 'to enroll, to wrap around' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to enroll, to wrap around' in Yanomami is 'akareai'.

Here are some examples:

- to enroll, to wrap around (inchoative).
  In Yanomami: akareai, inc.: 1. enrollarse a maru
How do you say 'to scrape one' in Yanomami?

The verb (transitive) 'to scrape one' in Yanomami is 'aka hõprai'.

Here are some examples:

- to scrape one's tongue with a vine (to remove residue).
  In Yanomami: aka hõprai: rasparse la lengua con un bejuco (para retirar adherencias)
How do you say 'fragment, piece, part' in Yanomami?

The noun 'fragment, piece, part' in Yanomami is 'akatahu'.

Here are some examples:

- (al caer) sobre las rocas punzantes, Danta (estalló) en muchos pedazos que se diseminaron.
  In Yanomami: pei kë ma pë pata namo shirikiopë hami shamariwë a pata akatahu yapikirariyoma (mit.)

- pieza de motor fuera de borda, pieza de repuesto de un motor
  In Yanomami: fmotoro akatahu (neol.)

- See: to speak (related form)
  In Yanomami: V. akatahu
How do you say 'to stick out the tongue' in Yanomami?
The verb (intransitive) 'to stick out the tongue' in Yanomami is 'aka wae'.
How do you say 'to clean one' in Yanomami?
The verb (intransitive) 'to clean one' in Yanomami is 'aka wamore'.
How do you say 'to tie (a knot, a bond)' in Yanomami?
The verb (transitive) 'to tie (a knot, a bond)' in Yanomami is 'do'.
How do you say 'very tight (a knot, a bond, a union)' in Yanomami?
The adjective 'very tight (a knot, a bond, a union)' in Yanomami is 'ãkikiprawë'.
How do you say 'firewood' in Yanomami?

The noun 'firewood' in Yanomami can be expressed as: 'kõã', 'totihiwë', 'ãkosho'.

Here are some examples:

- when the wood is wet
  In Yanomami: kõã yama ãyõ pë thai

- while we take care of the firewood and also it can be The word 'kõã' in Yanomami means 'wood'. It is an Noun.
  In Yanomami: ãrepo pë kãi tëapotayouhe: mientras nosotros nos ocupamos de la leña

- The container is made from the fruit of this plant.
  In Yanomami: Kõã hesi ãsho koa hesi.

- after a long time they ran out of firewood, and then they felt cold.
  In Yanomami: yãkumi totihiwë kõã thë ãsho pë ha hititiarariheni, pë wahaturayom a
How do you say 'dead and hard wood; wood that does not rot' in Yanomami?
The noun 'dead and hard wood; wood that does not rot' in Yanomami is 'amahi'.
How do you say 'immortal people who live underground (like amahi wood, which does not rot)' in Yanomami?
The noun 'immortal people who live underground (like amahi wood, which does not rot)' in Yanomami is 'akrëhë'.
How do you say 'to coil, to curl up' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to coil, to curl up' in Yanomami is 'akrete'.

Here are some examples:

- the immortal people curl up
  In Yanomami: akrëhë akrëtëai
How do you say '1. new leaf, bud still rolled up 2. small cotton ball, cotton ball that has shrunk from use' in Yanomami?
The noun '1. new leaf, bud still rolled up 2. small cotton ball, cotton ball that has shrunk from use' in Yanomami is 'ãkrõ'.
How do you say 'they' in Yanomami?

The pronoun 'they' in Yanomami can be expressed as: 'shee', 'thë'.

Here are some examples:

- they have to gather leaves and also it can be The word 'thë' in Yanomami means 'only'. It is a Particle.
  In Yanomami: thë hena pë ta yototoamapotuhe

- if only I could drink fresh water
  In Yanomami: ya thë u ha koarini

- if only I could enjoy a broth
  In Yanomami: ya thë pouku wãri ha totihiarini

- if only there was a stream of water nearby and also it can be The word 'thë' in Yanomami means 'the'. It is a Particle. and also it can be The word 'thë' in Yanomami means 'and'. It is a Particle. and also it can be The word 'thë' in Yanomami means 'time'. It is an Noun.
  In Yanomami: pei thë u aheteprao ha yairini

- some time passed, then he left and also it can be The word 'thë' in Yanomami means 'it'. It is a Pronoun.
  In Yanomami: thë no ha tetetaruni a kõrãyõma
How do you say 'leaves' in Yanomami?

The noun 'leaves' in Yanomami is 'hena'.

Here are some examples:

- they have to gather leaves and also it can be The word 'hena' in Yanomami means 'leaf'. It is an Noun.
  In Yanomami: thë hena pë ta yototoamapotuhe

- leaf of the banana plant
  In Yanomami: kuratha si hena
How do you say 'each' in Yanomami?

The pronoun 'each' in Yanomami is 'pë'.

Here are some examples:

- each will spread them out again and also it can be The word 'pë' in Yanomami means 'to be able'. It is a Verb (Intransitive).
  In Yanomami: pë thë patherio kõõpë kë

- yo comprobé que el hielo realmente podía curar and also it can be The word 'pë' in Yanomami means 'decapitar'. It is a Verb (Transitive).
  In Yanomami: preyura kë pëni pë thë haromai totihio tharei

- to decapitate
  In Yanomami: he pëprai: decapitar

- to injure a finger by hitting it with a sharp object
  In Yanomami: fimiki pëo

- when they were close, they gathered to bathe and also it can be The word 'pë' in Yanomami means 'I'. It is a Pronoun. and also it can be The word 'pë' in Yanomami means 'you'. It is a Pronoun.
  In Yanomami: pë owëai tëhë pë yãrimou kãi hiraoma
How do you say 'spread out' in Yanomami?

The verb (transitive) 'spread out' in Yanomami is 'patherio'.

Here are some examples:

- each will spread them out again.
  In Yanomami: pë thë patherio kõõpë kë
How do you say 'again' in Yanomami?

The adverb 'again' in Yanomami is 'kõõpë'.

Here are some examples:

- each will spread them out again.
  In Yanomami: pë thë patherio kõõpë kë
How do you say 'gather' in Yanomami?
The verb (transitive) 'gather' in Yanomami is 'amai'.
How do you say 'pith of the yagua palm' in Yanomami?
The noun 'pith of the yagua palm' in Yanomami is 'lmito'.
How do you say 'palm heart' in Yanomami?

The noun 'palm heart' in Yanomami is 'ãmo'.

Here are some examples:

- older brother, here is an excellent palm heart
  In Yanomami: yei kë ãmo wai wãnipraa kure: hermano mayor, he aquí un excelente palmito
How do you say 'thirst' in Yanomami?

The noun 'thirst' in Yanomami is 'amishi'.

Here are some examples:

- mother-in-law, I am thirsty
  In Yanomami: yape, ya amishi: suegra, tengo sed

- the child is hungry
  In Yanomami: ihiru a amishi: el niño tiene hambre

- (in a myth): he carried in his arms a small, wrinkled, hungry cachicamo
  In Yanomami: opo si ãikiwë kë a wai amishiri yakarema (mit.): llevaba en brazos a un pequeño cachicamo hambriento, de piel arrugada

- (in a myth about the south of the Orinoco): they caused Rahararitawë so much thirst that they made him run back and forth crying
  In Yanomami: rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama (mit.) (habla del sur del Orinoco.): ambos le provocaron a Rahararitawë tanta sed, que lo hicieron correr de un lado a otro llorando
How do you say 'barely audible' in Yanomami?

The adjective 'barely audible' in Yanomami is 'õmãyãri'.

Here are some examples:

- The devil's whisper is barely audible.
  In Yanomami: decilla del demonio õmãyãri apenas se escucha
How do you say 'central part of the sky' in Yanomami?
The noun 'central part of the sky' in Yanomami is 'ãmo misi'.
How do you say 'stomach ache' in Yanomami?

The noun 'stomach ache' in Yanomami is 'ãmoku nini'.

Here are some examples:

- To suffer from a stomach ache
  In Yanomami: ãmoku nini: sufrir del estómago

- To start having a stomach ache
  In Yanomami: ãmoku niniprou: llegar a tener dolor de estómago

- To suffer from (stomach ache).
  In Yanomami: ãmoku ninimou: padecer de
How do you say 'a proper name' in Yanomami?

The noun 'a proper name' in Yanomami is 'rahararitawë'.

Here are some examples:

- they provoked so much thirst to Rahararitawë that he ran crying from one side to the other.
  In Yanomami: rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama
How do you say 'to run from one side to the other' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to run from one side to the other' in Yanomami is 'apraro'.

Here are some examples:

- the woman was so afraid that she kept running from one side to the other
  In Yanomami: suwë kë a kiriri ruaprarou ha tikoikuni

- wherever the two women went, crying and holding hands, he followed them and stayed with them
  In Yanomami: suwë kë kipi miã kãi ipihipraropë ha a wãri pakihiapraroma
How do you say 'to go to different places' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to go to different places' in Yanomami is 'apotu'.

Here are some examples:

- they went to look for termite nests (each one to a different place)
  In Yanomami: ã r epo koko pë kãi tëapotayo kuhe

- he gave a name to all the rocks (in this example the subject is still, but acts at a distance on scattered objects)
  In Yanomami: mapë ãhã hititiapotayoma
How do you say 'upstream' in Yanomami?

The adverb 'upstream' in Yanomami can be expressed as: 'krake', 'nashiwë', 'paruhuru', 'sekisekima', 'yorofi', 'ãpuru'.

These words can function as: Adverb, Suffix.

Here are some examples:

- upstream speech.
  In Yanomami: ãpuru uﬁ

- it is sour
  In Yanomami: thë nashiwë

- it was sour.
  In Yanomami: thë nashioma

- we went down to the River of Rains and went back upstream
  In Yanomami: maatha u hami yamaki ha iroroparuni, yamaki iroroa mi ha yãmoparuhuruni

- Upstream is the river..
  In Yanomami: Sekisekima bla de río arriba.
How do you say 'speech' in Yanomami?

The noun 'speech' in Yanomami is 'uﬁ'.

Here are some examples:

- upstream speech.
  In Yanomami: ãpuru uﬁ
How do you say 'to continue doing something while moving' in Yanomami?

The suffix 'to continue doing something while moving' in Yanomami is 'aprara'.

Here are some examples:

- I am looking for them (while moving)
  In Yanomami: ya pë taeaprarai

- he was walking around looking for pijiguao palms
  In Yanomami: ihami rasha si taeaprarama

- he was advancing, cutting the vegetation and leveling the ground
  In Yanomami: enaha rë e thë pë pëaprarai kuaama, e thë hõãprarai kuaama
How do you say 'termite nest' in Yanomami?

The noun 'termite nest' in Yanomami is 'ãrepo'.

Here are some examples:

- while we take care of the firewood, they go to look for termite nests (to start the fire)
  In Yanomami: ãrepo pë kãi tëapotayouhe: mientras nosotros nos ocupamos de la leña, ellos van a buscar nidos de termitas (para encender el fuego)

- go look for termite nests so that we can make the fire for the food.
  In Yanomami: ãrepo kë pë ta yoahe, pëmaki ta iya: vayan a buscar nidos de termitas para que nosotros hagamos el fuego de la comida
How do you say 'termite' in Yanomami?

The noun 'termite' in Yanomami is 'koko'.

Here are some examples:

- The ant bites me
  In Yanomami: Kokoku ẽ koko

- I bite the basket and also it can be The word 'koko' in Yanomami means 'good'. It is an Adjective.
  In Yanomami: Ẽ koko a kõkõri

- good word.
  In Yanomami: orawë koko
How do you say 'striped catfish' in Yanomami?

The noun 'striped catfish' in Yanomami is 'araremi'.

Here are some examples:

- striped catfish; Pseudoplatystoma fasciatum and P. Tigrinum (Pimelodidae)
  In Yanomami: araremi: Zool., pez, bagre rayado; Pseudoplatystoma fasciatum y P. Tigrinum (Pimelodidae)
How do you say 'to call out to' in Yanomami?

The verb (intransitive) 'to call out to' in Yanomami is 'areremo'.

Here are some examples:

- to call out to them.
  In Yanomami: areremo– vb. intr. t areremou: lanzarle un llamado a los
How do you say 'a type of venomous snake' in Yanomami?

The noun 'a type of venomous snake' in Yanomami is 'mapanare'.

Here are some examples:

- The mapanares have come here to raise their heads! (lit.).
  In Yanomami: aroami kë ki oraki rë yareheikiyohe ë yë!
